conclusion: Analyze the forces and friction involved in the system to determine the condition for F1.
Identify forces on the block: F1 (left), F2 (upward), mg (downward), f (friction).
Identify forces on the plank: Mg (downward), normal force N (horizontal), frictional force f (opposite direction).
Maximum static frictional force is f_max = mu N, and f = mu N since the block is starting to move.
Apply Newton's second law vertically: F2 must overcome mg and f for the block to move upward.
Apply Newton's second law horizontally: Plank moves upward if horizontal forces cause it to pivot.
Normal force N is related to F1 and friction: N = F1, thus f = mu F1.
Condition for plank to move upward: F2 > mg + f + Mg, substituting f = mu F1.
Solve for F1: F1 > (F2 - mg - Mg)/mu.
Substitute given values: F1 > (F2 - 8 - 4)/0.20, leading to F1 > 5(F2 - 12).
